intro: Hazardia odontolepis, commonly known as the toothed hazardia, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads and leafy foliage. The plant typically grows in arid and semi-arid environments, showcasing adaptations to drought and poor soil conditions. Its leaves are usually narrow and often have a distinctive toothed or serrated edge, contributing to its common name. Hazardia odontolepis is often found in rocky or sandy soils, thriving in regions with low rainfall and high sunlight exposure.
